metadata.titleEn: Whole rock geochemical and mineral U - Pb geochronology data in the Changning area, Western Yunnan
metadata.description: This data including the zircon, monazite, garnet and cassiterite U - Pb ages and isotope data, and the geochemical data of the granite in Songshan tin deposite. Samples collected from songshan tin deposit, ore mineral is cassiterite, wall-rocks are biotite monzogranite and granodiorite. Single mineral were selected from the langfang Yuheng technology services company. Cathodoluminescence images and zircon U - Pb ages were finished at the SHRIMP Center at the Institute of Geology, Chinese Academy of Geological Science in Beijing. Monazite garnet, and cassiterite U - Pb ages and isotope dating were tested at the  Institute of Geology and Geophysics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, using multiple receive inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA - icp-ms).  All the whole-rock analyses were performed at Activation Laboratories, ltd., Canada. the uncertainties were reported as 95 % confidence limit with high reliability. Data suggest that tin mineralization in the Songshan deposit occurred at the end of Late Cretaceous, which is quite different from the ages of the Pinghejie granitic pluton emplaced. Thus we can concluded that the tin mineralization in the Songshan deposit occurred at the end of Late Cretaceous. It is another important metallogenic period in the Changning tin area.
metadata.instructions: Data stored in Excel format.File name called "Wallrock - MaiTra", on behalf of the whole rock of main trace elements data;File name called "Zr - Age", on behalf of the zircon Age;File name called "Mon - Age", on behalf of monazite Age;File name called "Grt - Age", on behalf of the garnet Age;File name called "Zr and Hf isotope", on behalf of zircon Hf isotope;File name called "Cst - Age", on behalf of the tin Shi Ding years data, the file name is called "Mon - Nd isotope", on behalf of monazite Nd isotopes.

background: The Songshan tin deposit is located in the northern Lincang granitic batholith along the Lancangjiang tin belt, Western Yunnan, southwestern China. The ore bodies mainly occur as tourmaline-quartz veins with NNE- and/or NW-trending in the Triassic Pinghejie granitic pluton, and the schist of the Proterozoic Songshan Formation. The previous study suggested the tin mineralization in the Songshan deposit should occur in the Triassic, but no directed age data support it. This hinders the understanding of the genesis of the Songshan tin deposit, especially the tin mineralization in the Lancangjiang tin belt. The zircon Hf isotopes (εHf(t) = – 22 ~ -12) and monazite Nd isotopes (εNd(t) = -13.04 ~ -11.80) indicate that the Pinghejie granitic pluton was derived from the remelting of Paleoproterozoic crust.
research objective: In this work, we present in-situ U-Pb ages for cassiterite from tin-bearing tourmaline-quartz vein hosted in the schist and monzogranite, and a set of new zircons, garnet U-Pb data, to constrain the age of the tin mineralization of the Songshan tin deposit, to compare the timing of cassiterite precipitation with granite crystallization, and provide clues to understand tin mineralization in the Lancangjiang belt.
challenges: This hinders the understanding of the genesis of the Songshan tin deposit, especially the tin mineralization in the Lancangjiang tin belt.
methods: Samples from different types of granites in the Pinghejie granitic pluton and ores were collected for petrochemical and geochronological analyses from the Songshan tin deposit. Zircon grains were collected from granodiorite, biotite monzogranite, and altered granite for U-Pb dating and Hf isotope analysis. Monazite grains were collected from biotite monzogranite and used for U-Pb dating as well as Nd isotope analysis. Garnet grains collected from skarn were used for U-Pb dating. Cassiterite grains collected from tin-bearing tourmaline-quartz-veins in skarn and biotite monzogranite were also used for U-Pb dating.
findings: These data suggest that tin mineralization in the Songshan deposit occurred at the end of Late Cretaceous, which is quite different from the ages of the Pinghejie granitic pluton emplaced and the formation of skarn. The paper concluded that the tin mineralization in the Songshan deposit occurred at the end of Late Cretaceous. It is another important metallogenic period in the Lancangjiang tin belt, which may be related to the subduction of the NeoTethys oceanic crust. The tin mineralization can not only occur in the magmatic arc, but also in the hinterland behind the magmatic arc.

Verification.Question: Is the confidence level for the geochemical analysis data reported as 95%?
Is there a challenge in understanding the tin mineralization in the Lancangjiang tin belt due to a lack of direct age data in previous studies?

Disjunctive.Question: Which method is primarily used for U-Pb dating in this field: LA-ICP-MS, ion probe, or another technique?
Which type of isotope analysis is more common for studying granite origins in this context: Hf isotopes, Nd isotopes, or another type?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the challenges faced in understanding the genesis of the Songshan tin deposit?

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a challenge faced in understanding the genesis of a tin deposit using geochemical data?
Example.Answer: A challenge is the lack of direct age data supporting the mineralization period, which hinders the understanding of the genesis of the Songshan tin deposit, especially within the broader context of the Lancangjiang tin belt.

Example.Question: What is an example of a finding derived from using isotopic analysis in geological studies?
Example.Answer: An example is the discovery that tin mineralization in the Songshan deposit occurred at the end of the Late Cretaceous, which differs from the emplacement ages of the associated granitic pluton, suggesting a separate metallogenic period possibly related to the subduction of the NeoTethys oceanic crust.

Feature Specification.Question: What specific attributes are considered to ensure the reliability and confidence in geochemical datasets?
Feature Specification.Answer: 95% data confidence level, high data credibility, advanced analytical techniques, multi-receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS)

Quantification.Question: How many types of minerals were used for U-Pb dating in the data collection process?
How many different laboratory locations were involved in the data collection and analysis process?

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'U-Pb dating' in the context of geochronological analysis?
Definition.Answer: U-Pb dating is a method used to determine the age of minerals, such as zircon, monazite, garnet, and cassiterite, by measuring the ratio of uranium to lead isotopes. It is a widely used technique in geochronology for dating geological events and understanding the timing of mineralization processes.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'in-situ analysis' when collecting geochronological data in geological studies?
Definition.Answer: In-situ analysis refers to examining minerals directly within their natural geological setting without extracting them from their rock matrix. This approach helps to maintain the context of the mineral's formation environment and is crucial for precise U-Pb dating and isotopic analysis, as seen in the analysis of zircon, monazite, garnet, and cassiterite grains.

Definition.Question: What does 'multi-receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (LA-ICP-MS)' mean in the context of isotope testing in geological research?
Definition.Answer: A multi-receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (LA-ICP-MS) is an analytical technique used to measure isotopic compositions and concentrations of elements in geological samples. It combines laser ablation to sample solid materials with mass spectrometry to analyze isotopic ratios, enabling precise U-Pb dating and isotopic analysis of minerals like monazite, garnet, and cassiterite.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when collecting geochemical and isotopic data from the Songshan tin deposit compared to other tin deposits in the Lancangjiang tin belt?
Comparison.Answer: The challenges in the Songshan tin deposit study stem from the initial lack of direct age data supporting the timing of tin mineralization, which hinders understanding of the deposit's genesis. In contrast, other tin deposits in the Lancangjiang tin belt may have different challenges, such as more complex tectonic settings or varying mineralization styles, affecting the ease of data collection and interpretation.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the geological history and processes in the Lancangjiang tin belt from the U-Pb dating and isotopic analysis techniques used in data collection?
Interpretation.Answer: The data collection methods, including U-Pb dating and isotopic analysis, suggest that the tin mineralization in the Songshan deposit occurred at the end of the Late Cretaceous. This timing is distinct from the emplacement of the Pinghejie granitic pluton and skarn formation, indicating a significant metallogenic period likely related to the subduction of the NeoTethys oceanic crust. This implies that tin mineralization can occur not only in a magmatic arc but also in the hinterland.

Interpretation.Question: How do the observed isotopic signatures from zircon and monazite contribute to understanding the source and evolution of the granitic plutons in Western Yunnan?
Interpretation.Answer: The isotopic signatures, such as zircon Hf isotopes (εHf(t) = – 22 ~ -12) and monazite Nd isotopes (εNd(t) = -13.04 ~ -11.80), indicate that the Pinghejie granitic pluton was derived from the remelting of Paleoproterozoic crust. This helps infer the source and evolutionary history of the granitic plutons in Western Yunnan, suggesting significant contributions from ancient crustal material.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the challenge in understanding the genesis of the Songshan tin deposit, particularly in relation to tin mineralization in the Lancangjiang tin belt?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenge in understanding the genesis of the Songshan tin deposit is primarily due to the lack of direct age data supporting the occurrence of tin mineralization in the Triassic, which hinders the understanding of its relationship to other geological events in the Lancangjiang tin belt.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons for employing different analytical methods such as LA-ICP-MS and whole-rock geochemistry in the data collection process?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Different analytical methods like LA-ICP-MS and whole-rock geochemistry are employed to achieve high confidence and reliability (95% confidence level) in the data, allowing for comprehensive geological and isotopic analyses that can accurately date mineralization events and understand geochemical compositions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the likely outcomes of using multi-receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) for U-Pb dating on the reliability and precision of geochronological data in mineral studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using LA-ICP-MS for U-Pb dating typically enhances the reliability and precision of geochronological data due to its ability to analyze isotopic compositions with high sensitivity and accuracy, as demonstrated in the data collection methods for zircon, monazite, garnet, and cassiterite in the specified region.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the choice of geochemical analysis conducted at international laboratories like actlabs in Canada affect the global comparability and standardization of geochemical datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Conducting geochemical analysis at internationally recognized laboratories such as actlabs in Canada enhances global comparability and standardization of geochemical datasets, ensuring high data confidence and credibility, which facilitates effective cross-regional geological comparisons and integrative research.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of collecting U-Pb dating data from zircon, monazite, garnet, and cassiterite minerals in the context of understanding the Songshan tin deposit?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to constrain the age of tin mineralization of the Songshan tin deposit, compare the timing of cassiterite precipitation with granite crystallization, and provide clues to understand tin mineralization in the Lancangjiang belt.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use isotopic analyses, such as zircon Hf and monazite Nd isotopes, in the investigation of the Pinghejie granitic pluton?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Isotopic analyses are important to indicate the source of the Pinghejie granitic pluton, which was derived from the remelting of Paleoproterozoic crust, thereby contributing to the understanding of the geological history and processes affecting the region.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the instrumental techniques and procedural steps involved in obtaining U-Pb ages from zircon, monazite, garnet, and cassiterite in the context of geochronological analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The instrumental techniques involve using a multi-receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (LA-ICP-MS) for U-Pb dating. Procedural steps include separating individual mineral grains like zircon, monazite, garnet, and cassiterite from their host rocks, preparing them as targets, capturing cathodoluminescence images, and then performing U-Pb dating at specialized centers equipped with the necessary instrumentation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the geochemical analysis of granitic rocks conducted to ensure reliable data for understanding the genesis of mineral deposits?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Geochemical analysis of granitic rocks is conducted by collecting samples, typically of granodiorite and biotite monzogranite, and sending them to specialized geochemical laboratories, such as actlabs in Canada, for comprehensive analysis. Such labs provide data with high confidence levels (95% confidence), ensuring the reliability needed to understand mineral deposit genesis.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural challenges might arise during the geochronological analysis of mineral deposits and how can they be addressed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Procedural challenges in geochronological analysis can arise from difficulties in accurately dating mineralization events due to complex geological histories. These challenges can be addressed by using a combination of different isotopic dating methods, such as U-Pb on zircon and other minerals, and integrating petrochemical analyses to provide a comprehensive timeline of geological events.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the accurate U-Pb dating of minerals such as zircon, monazite, garnet, and cassiterite in geological studies?
Enablement.Answer: The use of multi-receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) allows for precise U-Pb dating of minerals like zircon, monazite, garnet, and cassiterite by providing high accuracy and confidence in isotopic measurements.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection methods for U-Pb dating in mineral deposits face challenges in accurately determining the age of mineralization events?
Expectation.Answer: Data collection might face challenges due to the complexity of distinguishing between mineralization events and the emplacement of granitic plutons. The expectation might be to find concurrent dates, but differences in ages, as seen in the Songshan deposit where tin mineralization occurred at the end of Late Cretaceous, can complicate interpretations and require precise petrochemical and geochronological analyses.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset on granitic and mineral deposits in the Lancangjiang tin belt not include directed age data for certain mineralization events?
Expectation.Answer: The absence of directed age data could be due to previous assumptions that mineralization occurred simultaneously with granite formation, as suggested for the Songshan deposit. This hinders the understanding of the genesis, highlighting the expectation that dedicated U-Pb dating is needed to provide conclusive evidence of mineralization timing, which may not have been prioritized in earlier datasets.

Expectation.Question: Why is it expected that isotopic data, such as Hf and Nd isotopes, would provide insights into the genesis of the granitic pluton and tin mineralization?
Expectation.Answer: Isotopic data like Hf and Nd are expected to offer insights because they can trace the source material and geological processes involved. In the context of the Songshan deposit, these isotopes indicated the remelting of Paleoproterozoic crust, which guides researchers to expect isotopic analysis to help differentiate between crustal sources and processes contributing to both pluton formation and mineralization.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of the current data collection methods used for U-Pb dating in understanding tin mineralization events?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection methods, including U-Pb dating of zircon, monazite, garnet, and cassiterite grains, appear effective in constraining the timing of tin mineralization events. These methods provide precise age data that help distinguish between different geological periods and events, such as the Late Cretaceous tin mineralization and the emplacement of the Triassic granitic pluton. The high confidence level and reliability of the data suggest that these methods are well-suited for such studies.

Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of the current research approaches in identifying the relationship between granite crystallization and tin mineralization, and how might these approaches be improved?
Judgmental.Answer: The current research approaches, which involve comparative analysis of U-Pb dating between cassiterite from tin-bearing veins and zircon from granitic rocks, are effective in exploring the temporal relationship between granite crystallization and tin mineralization. These approaches provide insights into the distinct geological events responsible for mineralization. To improve these approaches, integrating additional isotopic analyses, such as Hf and Nd isotopes, along with more extensive petrochemical analysis, could offer deeper insights into the source and evolution of the mineralizing fluids and the geological processes involved.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how data collection methods ensure the accuracy and reliability of U-Pb dating in geochronology.
Assertion.Answer: The data collection methods involve single mineral separation techniques, cathodoluminescence imaging, and U-Pb dating using ion microprobes and multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS). These methods ensure high accuracy and reliability, with a confidence level of 95% in the dataset.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore and summarize data collection techniques used for determining U-Pb ages and isotopic compositions in granitic and ore samples within the mineralization studies of tin deposits.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection techniques involve in-situ U-Pb dating and isotopic analyses using samples from granites and ores. Zircon, monazite, garnet, and cassiterite grains from various rock types are collected for U-Pb dating and isotope analysis. Techniques such as LA-ICP-MS are utilized for precise age determination and isotopic composition analysis, enhancing understanding of tin mineralization timing and processes.
